newsitem.title: ETHIOPIA: Ethiopia says it has vast deposit of iron, nickel.
newsitem.headline: Ethiopia says it has vast deposit of iron, nickel.

text.p: Ethiopia said on Monday that it had vast proven deposits of iron and nickel which could be developed through the participation of mainly foreign investors.

The Ministry of Energy and Mines said results of exploration carried out by a joint team of Ethiopians and Koreans identified the existence of 58 million tonnes of iron reserves and 10.5 million tonnes of nickel in the west and south of the country.
In a statement that announced the results, the ministry did not give an estimate of what the reserves were worth.
The government of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi opened Ethiopia's mining sector to private investment in 1993.
At the time, the government issued mining proclamations and regulations that gave foreign investors incentives such as duty free imports of equipment and repatriation of profits.
The government also cut mining income tax to 35 percent from 45 percent and the Ethiopian government's free equity stake was reduced to two percent from a ceiling of 10 percent.
Since then, explorations have gathered pace and 12 foreign companies have signed agreements for the exploration of gold and base metals, gemstones and petroleum across Ethiopia.
Companies from Canada, the United States, Italy, Saudi Arabia and Ghana have signed gold exploration agreements with Ethiopia.
Italian and American concerns have also signed rights for the exploration of gemstone and petroleum, ministry documents showed.

The ministry said that the study also showed the existence of 3.4 million tonnes of sheet glass raw material in the central and southern parts and a reserve of more than 85 million tonnes of diatomite and 170 million tonnes of bentonite in the Rift Valley.
Ethiopia's rulers have turned to mining as a major future alternative source of hard currency earnings now dominated by coffee.
